narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: 3. The workload (weekly readings and writing assignments) was heavier than my other classes, but I learned the most from this class because of these directed assignments. I learned to balance work throughout the week, and it was useful to have a critiqued output at the end of every week.11. The instructor was quick to respond to any student questions or concerns, and gave thoughtful feedback. This was one of the strengths of the course for me.
This was the best course I took this semester. Karen is inspiring and empowering. You become a practical expert in the subject by the end.
This class is incredible!

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The weekly readings were incredibly informative and applicable to our discussions. The homework assignments not only taught us the skill of taking massive quantities of information and synthesizing, but also ensured that everyone came to class having not only done the reading, but also having spent serious time thinking about the key messages of each article.

Students in this course quickly developed a grasp of the primary literature while developing important analytical and writing skills. I left the class feeling confident in my ability to engage with other academics on the topics and write a clear, concise policy brief that I would feel comfortable giving to government officials or non-profit leaders. The format of the course provided a comfortable atmosphere where students from different academic backgrounds could discuss topics from the weekly readings and come to their own conclusions.

The class had an innovative format that allowed for the development of critical reading and writing skills. The mix of assignment types allowed for a good dissection of the material. Topic was fresh and we were able to get a lot from the Professor's deep engagement in the issue.
The discussions and the reading.

A) Course provided very thorough exposure to peer-reviewed literature on climate change and urbanization. B). it was clear that the main take-away from the class was a very specific and useful skill: writing a synthesis. C). Karen gave really interesting insight into IPCC and other international research groups on urbanization/global change. D). Peer review of S&A's via Dropbox worked really well. The process definitely gave more incentive to improve writing, and its quite helpful to read/critique others' writing style and synthesis skills. E). Due to the reading and writing intensity of the course, the students who decided to take the course were all very interested, engaged, and committed to the topic. Several students mentioned a unique camaraderie / bonding experience :).
Karen created a challenging course that was effective in teaching the skill of synthesis, while also exposing the class to a large body of knowledge.
The class discussions and "elevator pitch" presentations. Every class was great!! The almost intimate nature of the class also built bonds between the students.
Karen's a wonderful and insightful teacher, and the course was challenging and informative. She is the best source for urbanization trends at FES, and her syllabus is a wonderful reading list.
learning to get a good hold of a body of reading and discuss it in a useful context

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: I think overall the course was very good. A possible opportunity would be in expanding the oral assignment. Rather than saving the "pitch" presentations until the end of the semester, it would be useful and instructive to scatter them throughout the semester (ie. 2 pitches per week? a "pitch" session for each policy memo due date?) or have more than one pitch due- one in the beginning and one at the end.
I found group policy memo review sessions to be very useful throughout the course. This type of peer review and critique should be encouraged outside of the classroom as well as within.

A bit too much time spent on how to write the synthesis in the beginning few classes. Also, a lot of time spend on the administrative set up of the IPCC, whereas perhaps a website with the org structure would help answer those basic questions and allow us to get to the more meaty topics.Would be great to incorporate a field trip to an ongoing conference or government meeting on this topic to ground the academic literature.
It would have been nice to go on a field trip with the course, for example, to Doha.
None, it was a wonderful class.
Some of the readings were extremely specific (ex. emissions of concrete and green roof installations) and although they could be interesting, they made for a tedious read.
I honestly can't think of any.
view more models of good S&A's would help, maybe have a class to dissect one and really learn the structure after knowing the reading for that paper.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: YES! The discussion was so critical to reinforce the concepts from the readings. Karen was a great facilitator. However, it would be interesting also to give some general pointers on facilitating discussions and have students facilitate portions of the group discussion. That is another skill that could be conveyed through this course.
The discussions were very productive, although I would have liked a couple of lecture sessions from Karen.
n/a

narratives.question_text: What were the strengths and weaknesses of your teaching assistant
comments: Peter made great contributions to class discussions. He often asked really good questions or played "devil's advocate" to push students to elaborate further on their comments during class.He is a high-level thinker, and I enjoyed hearing his perspective and knowledge on climate change and urbanization.He graded S&A's fairly, and made helpful comments.

Instructor: Peter Anton Christensen  Peter was a VERY strong teaching assistant, with good feedback on assignments and helpful contributions/clarifications in class discussion. The class was made better by his presence.
Instructor: Peter Anton Christensen  The teaching assistant made a good effort to be available for student questions, and played a vital part in contributing to class discussions.
Instructor: Peter Anton Christensen  Teaching assistant was thoughtful and willing to assist students in how to move the class beyond the classroom.
Instructor: Peter Anton Christensen  Peter was excellent, responsive, and very helpful.
Instructor: Peter Anton Christensen  Peter was very strict but constructive in his comments.
Instructor: Peter Anton Christensen  I honestly felt like I would have benefitted from more feedback on my S&A's, I kept getting the same grade, and didn't know what to change.
Instructor: Peter Anton Christensen  confident and helpful

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: As a student new to the study of urbanization, this course allowed me to gain a huge amount of current knowledge on the subject without being basic in any way. I now have a better understanding of the drivers of urbanization and environmental change, which I will apply to future coursework at FES.
This course directly relates to my interest in urban studies and international sustainable development.
It aligns well and has inspired me to keep on my path of climate change planning.

This course is directly in line with my previous professional experience in urban planning. I found it quite thought-provoking to build in-depth knowledge on urbanization and climate change mitigation from a scientific/theoretical/global perspective and relate that to my prior experience working with local level planning and policy implementation.
This course was very helpful in shaping my course of study. I now know that I would like to pursue more urban-focused classes at FES.
In addition to learning about climate change, being able to synthesize a large amount of material is an important skill I learned which I know will help me in the rest of my career.
This is one of the only courses on urban areas - I really wish there were more!

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I was interested in studying urbanization and climate change during my first semester, and also wanted a highly structured course with clear skill outputs to begin my studies at FES.
Instructor and course topic.
Karen is my advisor and the topic aligned closely with my interests.

FES currently doesn't offer many courses directly related to urban sustainability issues, so I am eager to take these courses whenever they are available. Also, Karen Seto has a reputation as a challenging and engaging professor.
To take a course with Karen Seto, and to learn more about the impact of cities on climate change.
Because I am interested in anything related to urban areas and I wanted to take a class with Karen.
Karen Seto, urbanization, her focus on India and China, and a reading list on climate change selected by such a good professor.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Yes, the class exceeded my expectations.
Yes and then some.
I learned more than I could have imagined--but I had to work for it.
Expectations exceeded!
The class exceeded my expectations.
Exceeded expectations.
Yes
yes, exceeded

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was an optional grop that we used to reinforce the class material. It was fun and effective.

The peer reviews were helpful in refining style and learning to write for specific audiences. The group papers were sometimes more difficult to write than they would have been independently, but were realistic given the tasks that we may be asked to take on in a professional environment.
Group work on two of the policy memos was very beneficial. Provided a real life situation for policy work.

Students often self-organized to review and peer-edit policy memos. This is an indication not only of students' commitment to course topics, but also high esteem for each other, willingness to work together, and openness to feedback.
It was very hard to write a policy memo in a group - which I guess is the point.
meeting with classmates to discuss readings and peer review policy memos, very helpful

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Students who take this course need to dedicate themselves to putting in the time and effort necessary for the weekly assignmentsand discussions. The knowledge and skills gained is well worth the investment, and students will leave with solid skills that can be applied throughout their academic and professional careers. This was my favorite class of the semester.

Best class I've taken at F&ES so far! There is a lot of work, but the Professor provides good feedback and inspires working hard to improve quality of work. If you are at all interested in the issue area or want to gain hard writing and reading skills, definitely take this class.
You will work very hard (a lot of reading and writing) but it's absolutely worth it.

I highly recommend this course *IF* you are truly jazzed up about climate change mitigation and/or cities! Don't be dissuaded by the work load because it is absolutely worth it. Through the readings you will became one of the most knowledgeable people on these issues, and you will take away marketable skills in synthesis and science/policy writing styles.
Work hard, keep up with the readings, and immerse yourself, and the course will be very rewarding.
Take this class!!! You will get more out of it than you could ever imagine.
